output.conclusion: This course provides a foundational understanding of the principles governing the behavior of machines. By understanding kinematics, dynamics, and the mechanics of various machine components, students will be equipped to analyze and design effective mechanical systems.
output.introduction: Welcome to Theory of Machines! This course delves into the fundamental principles governing the motion and forces within machines. We will explore kinematics, dynamics, and the analysis of various machine components to understand how they function and interact.

chapters.description: Definition of kinematics, kinematic variables (displacement, velocity, acceleration), types of motion (translation, rotation, general plane motion).
Distinction between mechanisms and machines, basic components of a machine, examples of common mechanisms (linkages, cams, gears).
Concept of degrees of freedom, Kutzbach criterion for planar mechanisms, examples of calculating degrees of freedom.
Introduction to four-bar linkages, Grashof's law, classification of four-bar linkages (crank-rocker, double-crank, double-rocker).
Description of slider-crank mechanisms, applications in engines and compressors, kinematic analysis of slider-crank mechanisms.
Concept of inversions, examples of inversions of four-bar and slider-crank mechanisms, applications of different inversions.
Definition of dynamics, Newton's laws of motion, concepts of force, mass, and acceleration.
Calculation of inertia forces and torques, effect of inertia on machine components, balancing of rotating masses.
Methods for dynamic force analysis, free body diagrams, application of Newton's laws to machine components.
Introduction to cams and followers, types of cams and followers, displacement diagrams, velocity and acceleration analysis.
Methods for designing cam profiles, consideration of jerk and other higher-order derivatives, applications of cams and followers.
Static and dynamic balancing, balancing machines, balancing of single and multiple rotating masses.
Basic gear terminology (pitch circle, module, pressure angle), types of gears (spur, helical, bevel, worm).
Simple, compound, and epicyclic gear trains, velocity ratio calculations, applications of gear trains.
Causes and effects of interference and undercutting in gears, methods to avoid interference.
Types of belt drives (flat, V-belt), velocity ratio, slip, power transmission, belt tension calculations.
Types of chain drives, roller chains, silent chains, velocity ratio, power transmission, chain tension calculations.
Types of friction, laws of friction, friction in machine elements (bearings, clutches, brakes).
